chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Current palpitations
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with current palpitations.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I admit a person with current palpitations?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange emergency admission for a person with current palpitations and:
    • Ventricular tachycardia (VT).
    • Persistent supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Before deciding to admit, if trained and competent to do so, attempt to terminate the SVT if appropriate by:
      • Valsalva manoeuvre — for example the person blows into a syringe whilst lying down (face up) for 15 seconds.
      • Carotid sinus massage — ensure that a defibrillator is available, as very rarely terminating an SVT can provoke other arrhythmias. Ideally, record an electrocardiogram (ECG) continuously during and after the procedure.
    • Haemodynamic instability (hypotension and/or tachycardia).
    • High risk structural heart disease including ischemic heart disease.
    • Features suggestive of a serious underlying cardiac cause or complication:
      • High degree atrioventricular block on ECG.
      • Significant breathlessness.
      • Chest pain.
      • Syncope or near syncope.
      • Family history of sudden cardiac death under the age of 40 years.
      • Onset of palpitations precipitated by exercise.
    • Consider admission for a person with current palpitations and evidence of a serious or life-threatening systemic cause, such as thyrotoxicosis, severe anaemia, or sepsis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to admit a person with current palpitations are based on expert opinion in the European guideline Management of patients with palpitations: a position paper from the European Heart Rhythm Association [Raviele, 2011], the BMJ Best Practice guideline Evaluation of palpitations [BMJ Best Practice, 2018], UK clinical guidelines Pathways for cardiology symptoms in primary care [Benett, 2012] and Guidance on the management of palpitations in primary care [Fay, 2018]; together with expert opinion in the review articles Diagnostic approach to palpitations [Abbott, 2005], 10 steps before you refer for palpitations [Wolff, 2009b], Outpatient approach to palpitations [Wexler, 2011], and Assessment of palpitations [Gale, 2016].

  • The description of a Valsalva manoeuvre is taken from a Cochrane review Effectiveness of the Valsalva manoeuvre for reversion of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) [Smith, 2015]. It should be noted that although the Valsalva manoeuvre is a commonly used first-line technique to restore normal sinus rhythm the authors did not find sufficient evidence to support or refute its effectiveness.

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with current palpitations not requiring urgent admission?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer to cardiology, the urgency depending on clinical judgement, people with:
    • Atrial flutter.
    • Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) terminated by the Valsalva manoeuvre or carotid sinus massage.
    • Pre-excitation/Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.
    • Ventricular extrasystoles (ectopics) where:
      • Underlying heart disease is suspected from the clinical assessment and/or electrocardiogram (ECG).
      • Extrasystoles are frequent or ventricular tachycardia is suspected.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on referral of people with current palpitations are based on expert opinion in the European guideline Management of patients with palpitations: a position paper from the European Heart Rhythm Association [Raviele, 2011], the BMJ Best Practice guideline Evaluation of palpitations [BMJ Best Practice, 2018], and UK clinical guidelines Pathways for cardiology symptoms in primary care [Benett, 2012] and Guidance on the management of palpitations in primary care [Fay, 2018]; together with expert opinion in the review articles Diagnostic approach to palpitations [Abbott, 2005], 10 steps before you refer for palpitations [Wolff, 2009b], Outpatient approach to palpitations [Wexler, 2011], and Assessment of palpitations [Gale, 2016].

Ventricular extrasystoles (ectopics)
  • The recommendations on referring people with frequent extrasystoles or any suggestion of ventricular tachycardia (VT) are from a review article Treating patients with ventricular ectopic beats [Ng, 2006] that advises that people with frequent extrasystoles or any suggestion of VT should be referred to cardiology.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage people in primary care following initial assessment?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Admission or immediate referral are generally not indicated if palpitations are isolated, the 12 lead electrocardiogram is normal, and if symptoms are:
    • Not provoked by exercise.
    • Not associated with lightheadedness, syncope, persistent breathlessness, or chest pain.
    • Not associated with a history or signs of structural heart disease, heart failure, or hypertension.
    • Not associated with a family history of sudden cardiac death.
  • For people who do not need to be admitted or referred, or who are awaiting referral:
    • Arrange blood tests including a full blood count, urea and electrolytes, thyroid function tests, liver function tests, and HbA1c to help identify any underlying cause. If any is/are identified, manage or refer appropriately.
    • Carry out a cardiovascular risk assessment and manage risk factors as appropriate. See the CKS topic on CVD risk assessment and management for further information.
    • Give lifestyle advice on reducing or avoiding stress, caffeine, alcohol, smoking, and drugs that can precipitate or exacerbate palpitations.
    • For people with atrial fibrillation — see the CKS topic on Atrial fibrillation for advice on management.
    • For people with atrial or ventricular extrasystoles (ectopics) — if there are no features of underlying heart disease and palpitations are infrequent, reassure the person that the palpitations are unlikely to be a cause for concern.
    • For people with sinus tachycardia — manage the underlying cause where possible.
  • If palpitations remain poorly controlled and symptomatic, consider referral to cardiology.
  • Give advice about driving and work if appropriate.
    • The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) regulations state that:
      • For Group 1 entitlement, driving must cease if an arrhythmia has caused or is likely to cause incapacity. Driving may be permitted when the underlying cause has been identified and controlled for at least 4 weeks.
      • For Group 2 entitlement, the driver is disqualified from driving if an arrhythmia has caused or is likely to cause incapacity. Driving may be permitted when the underlying cause has been identified and the arrhythmia is controlled for at least 3 months.
      • See the DVLA guide Assessing fitness to drive – a guide for medical professionals for further information.
    • People with certain occupations, for example those working at height or with potentially dangerous machinery, will need to stop work until a diagnosis is confirmed or the underlying condition is treated.
  • Offer general information and advice about palpitations. Patient leaflets are available from the NHS, Patient.info, and the British Heart Foundation.
